ansible/roles/common/templates/conf/outp.message:
A brief explanation of this buffer [] weirdness for prospective reviewers.
Fluentd docs (https://docs.fluentd.org/configuration/buffer-section#blank-chunk-keys) explain that <buffer> without a argument uses the default chunk keys specified by the output plugin if available. 
In our case the output plugin is @type file and by default it uses the time chunk key (https://github.com/fluent/fluentd/blob/master/lib/fluent/plugin/out_file.rb#L63).
By providing [] we override the default so that chunks are written to a single file without a timestamp - this allows logrotate to manage/rotate/delete the files as intended.
Can we get this in commit message?
Is there a reason we don't have the <format> section here?

Looks like that was decided when fluentd was first added (https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/d3d4a933be797d1dc7ab156529878bc0c00f9e1c).
The flags used in <format> section control whether tag/time are injected into the logfile (https://docs.fluentd.org/v/0.12/formatter/out_file#output_tag-boolean-optional-defaults-to-true). 
I suspect this was done because the haproxy logs already include date and program name at the start of the log where swift does not (see https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/logs.html for current swift log format).
let's add some comment in the file, so it's more-or-less explained for future references?

I've added some comments on the parts changed by this PR. Further effort to document the fluentd config would be useful though. 
There is also a mix of fluentd v0.12 and v1 config syntax (https://docs.fluentd.org/quickstart/update-from-v0.12) in use - see https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1919179 for one example of a bug this causes. 
I suggest we resolve this bug and improve the documentation in the PR to address that.
Is there a reason we're not doing this for swift?
(FWIW, I answered on the backported change.)

> Patch Set 1:

> I do wonder why we have an identical copy of this file to the one in ceilometer in ceilometer/pipeline/data/event_definitions.yaml. Is there one in the container we can use?


If not used an override mechanism (https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/788479899b0ea291ac2a2284549b49906e506fea/ceilometer/event/converter.py#L281), Ceilometer will use its default file. The question is then, why overriding it by default in Kolla-ansible? We could use the default that Ceilometer provides, and then if needed, we could create a process to override it with some custom config set by the user via the "definitions_cfg_file" option: https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/788479899b0ea291ac2a2284549b49906e506fea/ceilometer/event/converter.py#L28
If we are not customising the file in kolla-ansible, I agree that using the one in ceilometer by default would be better.

whitebox_tempest_plugin/api/compute/test.message: So quick initial first remark: I was imagining this would get turned into a list of CPUs, I think it would simplify a lot of the logic below.
I believe the method for #L269 of the new PS should address this.

I would ideally like to avoid adding new uses of list_compute_hosts(), and eventually replace everything we currently have and remove the method entirely. It starts to get problematic for envs with more than 2 hosts.
I agree I just started doing the NSM removal for some other tests and I am not super crazy about this approach there either.  If there is a path that can remove this I think that is the right move.

Building on the theme of wanting to avoid list_compute_hosts() and only inspection of the host we landed on to figure out the dedicated_set config, I keep coming back to thinking there's a way to make all of this simpler.

I think if we make a couple of assumptions about how the environment is deployed, we can make the test code simpler and quicker...

With two compute hosts A and B, we need dedicated_set(A) disjoint from dedicated_set(B).

If we assume that the SRIOV card is on the same NUMA node on all compute hosts, we can make CONF.whitebox_hardware.physnet_numa_affinity to be a list of CPUs (or create a new option for backwards compatibility with tests that haven't been converted yet), and have dedicated_set(A) such that physnet_numa_affinity is a subet of dedicated_set(A)

We then boot a VM with num_cpus = len(physnet_numa_affinity)

At this point we have no choice but to go on the host to read its dedicated_set. 

We create a new flavor with num_cpus = len(dedicated_set) - len(physnet_numa_affinity)

Boot a VM with that flavor, assert it's pinned to dedicated_set but outside physnet_numa_affinity.

As an example, if we have two compute hosts with both NUMA0 = 0,1,2,3 and NUMA1 = 4,5,6,7, we can have cpu_dediated_set = 0,1,2,3,4,5 on A and cpu_dedicated_set = 6,7 on B. We'd have physnet_numa_affinity = 0,1,2,3. We boot a VM with cpus=4, it lands on A, we boot another VM on host A with cpus=2 (computed from len(0,1,2,3,4,5) - len(0,1,2,3)), and assert that it lands on the correct CPUs 5,6.

Makes sense? Or are we swinging the pendulum too far in the other direction (everything declarative) now?
I believe the latest PS should address simplifying the code, removes NSM, and adds declarations without being too declartive. Let me know what you think though.

I'll need to look at the current tests we have and the future pci numa affinity we have planned. My only concern is for this to work we'd have to make the assumption that:
#1) cpu_dedicated_sets are different for every host in the deployment
#2) cpu_dedicated_set for one and only one host is on the NUMA with affinity.  All other hosts would have to have a cpu_dedicated_set that does not have affinity.

I just worry if this could impose any restrictions on other tests now or in the future if only one host can use cpu_dedicated_sets from a specific NUMA and all other hosts must divide up their dedicated_sets to some other NUMA(s) for the test to work.

Just to clarify our AMD Sev and SR-IOV deployments are setup to follow the assumption from #1 but they still have cpu_dedicated_sets that can exists on a NUMA with affinity without them all being the same value for each compute e.g.

Correct. Since both are always created together (either - and only - here or in the migration script that runs during upgrade procedure), finding (or not) the 'ptp4l-legacy' instance is an indication that also 'phc2sys-legacy' should be found (or not).

I suppose here the operation 'with connection()' is not needed to be more atomic to handle case of interim failure as this script would be invoked during an upgrade, so any failure would fail the upgrade would require abort, so understand the need for modularity by splitting out the methods each with their own 'with connection()'

Besides modularity, having separated cursors ensure they are serialized, according to this psycopg2 mention: "using many cursors on the same connection, all the commands will be executed in the same session (and in the same transaction if the connection is not in autocommit mode), but they will be serialized", found here: https://www.psycopg.org/docs/usage.html#thread-and-process-safety.

In a previous draft version I had the same cursor used for consecutive SQL operations, and got in trouble with commands that were incomplete while others were being already issued.

swift/common/daemon.py.message:
Python's support for interfaces is pretty weak.  The existence of this method is meant to highlight that *at a minimum* a subclass isn't really a daemon unless it's has a conf and logger attribute.  Your subclass of Daemon must either use this __init__ or define a method that fulfills the contact [1]

In the run method below you can see that the implementation depends on it - unless the subclass also implements it's own run method.

1. The contract is pretty straight forward - so all current subclasses just do it on their own while doing other __init__ stuff.  If it offends your sensibilities for DRYness you could refactor the implementations to use a base implementation that's more condusive to re-use.

specs/xena/distributed-metadata-data-pat.message: what if the same range will be user by some user in their private network?

It's a common case, what if user set private subnet with external network. A simple answer, we just do not let it happen. Cloud operators needs to restrict such case. Typically cloud prividers will limit tenant subnet IP range to "IPv4 Private Address Space". So usually, we chose a subnet of this 100.64.0.0/10 [1] for it in a data center.

[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6598
Ack
same question here: what if user will use that vlan id in their provider network?
Ack
Tenant traffic will not be send to this bridge, so it's ok to override with any provider vlan IDs.
nit: Metadata
Done
what MAC+IP it is? VM or Meta? Or something else?

When your VM trying to access 169.254.169.254:80, what should the dest MAC + IP be?
The dest IP is clear, it is 169.254.169.254. The complicated case is the dest MAC.
We have three scenarios:
a. if your VM has only one default route which point to gateway, so this mac should be gateway MAC.

b. if your VM has a route which directly point to 169.254.169.254 (for instance, to 169.254.169.254 via 192.168.1.2 (the dhcp port IP), normally, this is set by original DHCP-agent and metadata mechanism), so some ARP responder(s) will be added for such DHCP port IPs, in case of upgrading. A fake mac will be responded for these DHCP port IPs.

c. if your VM has a link route which is telling us 169.254.169.254 is directly reachable. So an ARP responder for 169.254.169.254 will be added. So the dest MAC will be a fake one as well.
Ack

just an idea: if You would do something similar to what ovn is doing and run haproxy process per network on the node, You could plug it directly into br-int and make all that stuff a lot easier. Or am I missing something?

This is a traditional topology for neutron ml2-ovs, do specific work on specific bridge, something like tunnel bridge and various provider network bridges. And more things we do not want to mix the new flows with those complicated list on br-int. So an independent bridge makes sense. More about ovn is that OVN will create haproxy process for one network, not to use one process for all VMs in one host. So the solution here is an advanced progress. Regard to the flows and the CIDRs you mentioned in the team meeting, IMO, it's all in-memory data, it is not heavy load process and namespace. So it is light. And after counting the flows for each VM, it is only 5 flows each. Assuming you have 1000 VMs in a host, it's only 5000 static entries. It's better than the related flows of security group which has 100K+ level of flows usually.
For security this needs to be after rules protecting against mac spoofing.

dl_vlan=<local_vlan_1>,dl_src=fa:16:3e:4a:fd:c1,nw_src=192.168.1.10

And with this implementation we can stop using the route pushing hacks, because as long as the guest OS sends metadata traffic out (to any dst mac) we can catch it on br-int. So in the long term we can slowly kill two cases out of the three (probably killing b and c makes sense). But I understand we need to handle them for the upgrade.
If the routes of b and c are still in the VMs, or the subnets do not change the routes for new created VMs, we still need to handle these cases.

******************************
Troubleshooting quality checks
******************************

To be sure your local setup is using the latest quality check files, we recommend that you delete your local ``.tox`` folder on a regular basis (for example, every 90 days). Typically this folder is a subfolder of the location where you cloned the ``\docs`` repository.

When you run a ``tox`` command, Sphinx will download and install any needed packages based on a ``requirements.txt`` file. 

If you run ``tox -e docs`` and see a failure message similar to ``The enchant C library was not found and maybe needs to be installed.`` try the following steps:

#. Check that the docs installed list shows both ``pyenchant==3.2.2`` and ``sphinxcontrib-spelling==7.3.2`` packages. If not, delete the ``.tox`` folder and run ``tox -e docs`` again. If both packages are present, continue with the next step.

#. Manually install the enchant C library with the following command:

Might be nice to add an example, based on the IPA one:

Example: Configuring custom DIB elements
----------------------------------------

Sometimes it is useful to use custom DIB elements that are not shipped with DIB
itself. This can be done by sharing them in a git repository.

.. code-block:: yaml
   :caption: ``ipa.yml``

   ipa_build_dib_elements_extra:
     - "my-element"

   ipa_build_dib_git_elements:
     - repo: "https://git.example.com/custom-dib-elements"
       local: "{{ source_checkout_path }}/custom-dib-elements"
       version: "master"
       elements_path: "elements"

In this example the ``master`` branch of
https://git.example.com/custom-dib-elements would have a top level ``elements``
directory, containing a ``my-element`` directory for the element.

Seems like it'd be roughly the same level of effort to just always do this...

If we *really* want to avoid the re-serialization overhead when possible, something like

 obscure_params = obscure_map.get('params', [])
 new_params = []
 any_obscured = False
 for k, v in req.params.items():
     if k in obscure_params:
         new_params.append((k, self.obscure_sensitive(v)))
         any_obscured = True
     else:
         new_params.append((k, v))
 if any_obscured:
     req.params = new_params

would avoid the current double-deserialization. (I'm still torn about req.param ... it's heavier weight than I typically like for a property...)

This isn't true following https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/5a4d3bdf -- you can now have valid sigs that are

* 40 chars (hex-encoded sha1 sig)
* 64 chars (hex-encoded sha256 sig)
* 50 or 51 chars (base64-encoded sha256 sig, with or without padding '=')
* 93-95 chars (base64-encoded sha512 sig, again +/- padding)

or even as short as 33 chars (!) if you do a base64-encoded sha1 sig.

While I'm generally positive on adding this information to the ceph-client relation, I'd like to understand if there's a specific reason for the change. Any time we add information to the relation is one more thing that must be maintained and tested, so I want to ensure that we have a purpose, in the form of a bug or a spec.

Hi Chris:

Bug is here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-prometheus-ceph-exporter/+bug/1931745
Actually charm-prometheus-ceph-exporter doesn't support new ceph version, it will run into error. Blocking it proactively will stop similar confusion in future.

Re: functest, that's a good point. But this change involves changes in 3 repos:
1. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-ceph-mon/+/805600
2. https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-interface-ceph-client/+/805582
3. https://code.launchpad.net/~ziyiwang/charm-prometheus-ceph-exporter/+git/charm-prometheus-ceph-exporter/+merge/407378

When this feature is not implemented in the other 2 repos, it's hard to test against it. Also, since the blocking happens in prometheus-ceph-exporter charm, I would think the best place to add func test is in there.

I'd like to see a bug or a spec raised that this change resolves. It makes it a lot easier to track _why_ a decision was made in the past, as well as ensuring that we actually cover the request.

Given that the reason for this change is to deal with a charm that's not included in this testing, I'd also prefer to see functional validation that the other side works as expected for Ceph versions prior to Nautilus, and then blocks correctly with versions after (inclusive)

Hi Chris: Originally we relate prometheus-ceph-exporter to ceph-mon to get metrics. From ceph version nautilus, ceph provides builtin metrics so we don't need prometheus-ceph-exporter any more. The reason we need ceph version in relation is: we want to block prometheus-ceph-exporter when a ceph-mon unit with new ceph version is relating to it.
I understand this looks overkill, but we didn't find better solution to let prometheus-ceph-exporter know ceph version. Do you have any suggestions, please ?

Hi Chris, after discussion with James Troup, we decided to drop above 3 patches including this one. Instead, we choose to just simply add a deprecated notice in prometheus-ceph-exporter charm. Thank you for your input!

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
This makes me realize that I added ovsdbapp's RowView as an idea for a backend-agnostic read-only version of a Row, but that I didn't add it to ovsdbapp/api.py and left the single implementation in backend/ovs_idl. It's not nice to have to do a transaction for every logical switch (and look up the ls again by name in memory) when we already have the data.

We can leave this as-is for now, but I'll try to get something up making it official that code outside of command objects should be able to use RowViews (which is a little different than just accessing idl.tables directly.

Looking at the RowView code, it probably does need some more isolation before being used this way (either something like making it a namedtuple like is used in indexing, or at least making a copy of the row that is stored in it).

neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py.message:
Why native-tagged?

If I set native-tagged:

 ovs-vsctl clear Port $iface trunks
 ovs-vsctl set Port $iface tag=4095
 ovs-vsctl set Port $iface vlan_mode=native-tagged

Then the normal action eventually drops the packet somewhere, but first it floods:

 # ovs-appctl ofproto/trace br0 in_port=$ofport,dl_vlan=0
 Flow:  in_port=4,dl_vlan=0,dl_vlan_pcp=0,vlan_tci1=0x0000,dl_src=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_dst=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_type=0x0000
 
 bridge("br0")
 -------------
  0. priority 0
     NORMAL
      -> no learned MAC for destination, flooding
 
 Final flow: unchanged
 Megaflow: recirc_id=0,eth,in_port=4,dl_vlan=0,dl_vlan_pcp=0,dl_src=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_dst=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_type=0x0000
 Datapath actions: pop_vlan,push_vlan(vid=4095,pcp=0),1,3

However if I set trunk:

 ovs-vsctl clear Port $iface tag
 ovs-vsctl set Port $iface vlan_mode=trunk
 ovs-vsctl set Port $iface trunks=4095

Then it drops the untagged packets right away:

 # ovs-appctl ofproto/trace br0 in_port=$ofport,dl_vlan=0
 Flow: in_port=4,dl_vlan=0,dl_vlan_pcp=0,vlan_tci1=0x0000,dl_src=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_dst=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_type=0x0000
 
 bridge("br0")
 -------------
  0. priority 0
     NORMAL
      >>>> dropping VLAN 0 packet received on port vnet5 not configured for trunking VLAN 0 <<<<
      >> disallowed VLAN VID for this input port, dropping
 
 Final flow: unchanged
 Megaflow: recirc_id=0,eth,in_port=4,dl_vlan=0,dl_src=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_dst=00:00:00:00:00:00,dl_type=0x0000
 Datapath actions: drop
Reading through the doc I thought it should work absolutely the same as trunk with trunks=4095, now I see the difference. Thanks for checking! I will change back to trunks

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Raised https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/os-traits/+/818514 - will add a "Depends-On" here when I implement a prefilter and upload the change.

Added a pre-filter for requests that contain VNIC_TYPE_SMARTNIC ports in them: hosts that do not have either the relevant compute driver capability COMPUTE_REMOTE_MANAGED_PORTS or PCI device pools with "remote_managed" devices are filtered out early. Presence of devices actually available for allocation is checked at a later point by the PciPassthroughFilter.

Implemented additional filtering logic in PciDeviceStats so that remote_managed VFs aren't used unless explicitly asked for, remote_managed PFs are not supported at all (see the reasoning in commit message). Mixed-use scenarios for VFs are supported: e.g. one could request a remote-managed VF and a legacy SR-IOV or hardware offloaded VF (it's a questionable platform configuration but we need to take this into account nevertheless).

nova/pci/stats.py.message: what if whitelist passed via dev_filter?

Thanks for following up on this. I think we are safe.

1) When this is called from the pci tracked then it is passing in a whitelist that allows remote managed ports. The tracker lives in the compute service that at startup already did the check and passed it. 

2) When this is called from the scheduler then the whitelist is instantiated here and from the scheduler perspective we are supporting such ports by selecting a host that supports such ports during the scheduling.

I also don't have much alternative. We created a Whitelist object that has multiple reasons to exists. i) validate the config ii) to serve as a data structure holding the parsed config information. So in some case we need the logic from both #i) and #ii) but in other case we only need the logic of #ii) and we don't want to care about #i). Probably we cloud have two classes (in some relationship) to cover the two cases and use the simpler one in the scheduler. Still in the compute we have cases when we recreate the whitelist object instead of reusing the validated one from the startup. So this direction would be some nasty refactoring. 

I'm OK with the current structure.

In the second upload I covered the case where this happens. This isn't a guarantee that other things that might create a PciDeviceStats will supply the option correctly but then I do not see any other places where we might want to do that.

I don't have a good alternative to passing a parameter but I had a completely different approach in mind which would expose a property on the Whitelist object that would indicate whether the remote_managed tag was used there which I could then use for early validation. However, this does seem more cumbersome as I have to track it on the PciDeviceSpec objects as well and would would need to raise an exception elsewhere by checking this property.

Hopefully what I have now is better.
thanks!

In the spec I focused on the DPU case where a host is separate and the implementation decouples VIF plugging from Nova for that reason.

The "trivial" case for remotely-managed devices is when they are programmed (both vif plugging and flows) by the networking agent on the same host. In other words, the current cross-project feature implementation allows networking agents to run remotely but does not mandate it.

So while the feature is focused on the remote management use-case we could also use this feature for non-DPU hardware-offload capable NICs with the switchdev capability which is an already supported feature (https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-ovs-offload.html). The difference would be that VFs would need to be marked as "remote_managed: true" in the passthrough_whitelist, VNIC_TYPE_SMARTNIC port type would need to be used and `--binding-profile '{"capabilities": ["switchdev"]}'` would not be needed during port creation.

Practically, this case may be useful for testing the new code-path if DPUs are not available in a lab. While we've been testing with a DPU, it allows more machines to be used for testing.

That does not make me want to change the tag name that much but I think it's worth calling out.
Yeah, probably needs a note in the doc but I'm OK to keep the intention as managing "remote" devs.

Made some changes to allow & test this. I have to inspect the PF attributes exposed via sysfs in order to do some validation.

Fortunately the SR-IOV spec (1.0+) defines "VF Device ID" that a PF has to provide and which has to be used for each VF and the product ID of a VF has to match the PF product ID. So we can validate a VF product ID and vendor ID just by looking at the PF attributes.

My earlier comment on IRC regarding a "management VF" was not correct: it's actually a management PF and it appears to be that only one VF product ID can be used per PF so we do not need an overly complex validation logic.

Trying to sum up the cases:

1) Matching VFs of a specific PF only: PF PCI address is specified with a vendor and device IDs of a VF.
   (***will work*** with the current code as we are matching a VF by a PF address at the compute node side during device discovery and dev_type=='type-VF' in the resulting pool send to the scheduler)

  see the trace: https://paste.opendev.org/show/bRN19VBEW2cs6Wu2TOG3/

  Example: passthrough_whitelist = {"address": "0000:82:00.0", "vendor_id": "15b3", "product_id": "101e", "physical_network": null, "remote_managed": "true"}
  where 0000:82:00.0 is an address of a PF.
  AND "101e" is a product id of a VF.
  
2) PF PCI address is specified in the whitelist + remote_managed tag but the vendor and product ID belong to a PF.
   (will be filtered with the current code)

  Example: passthrough_whitelist = {"address": "0000:82:00.0", "physical_network": null, "remote_managed": "true"}
  
  where "a2d6" is a product id of a PF.
  
3) (will be filtered with the current code) PF PCI address is specified along with PF vendor and product id in the whitelist + remote_managed tag;
  (will be filtered with the current code)

  Example: passthrough_whitelist = {"address": "0000:82:00.0", "vendor_id": "15b3", "product_id": "a2d6", "physical_network": null, "remote_managed": "true"}
  
  where "a2d6" is a product id of a PF.


In cases (2) and (3) the PFs will end up being exposed in pools and need to be filtered for allocation purposes but they could be used, for example, to avoid filtering VFs that do not have the remote_managed tag specified in the pci_whitelist for which we automatically set it to false.

So when you say "consider PF that are tagged as remote managed" do you mean that I need to support cases (2) and (3)?

Does that seem sane or do I misunderstand it?

i guess we could consider PF that are tagged as remote managed as meaning
the VF assocated with the PF are remote managed.

for example we support using the PF address with the VF vendor id and product id to whitelist the vfs fo a give pf for use.

in such a case a physical_network tag on the PF is used for the physical_network of the VF transitivly. it would be consitent to treath the remote_managed tag the same. in such a case the PF is not aviableble for schduling and typicaly it will not be repored in the db as a resouce but its adress will be used as the parent.

that is hte behavior i would expect form the remote managed flag too.


this check is still valid in the even that the PF has no vender id/product id defiend of the vendor id and product id match the PF. in such a case however instead of catching it here i would prefer if we rasised and error and prevent the agent form startign with the inlvalid config by raising an error as part of host instialisation/agent start up when we are parsign the whitelist and initalising the pci tracker.

Implemented a check in devspec.py:PciDeviceSpec.match. This will be called early on startup of Nova compute before data obtained from Libvirt is converted to pools:

_setup_pci_tracker -> pci_tracker.update_devices_from_hypervisor_resources(dev_json) -> self.dev_filter.device_assignable(dev) -> spec.match(dev)

device_assignable will return `False` for PFs marked as `remote_managed` and a warning will be logged in the devspec code.

Also removed the pool check for remote_managed PFs from PCI stats and reworked unit tests.
Done

Another case in addition to the ones above:

4) InstancePCIRequest may potentially request PFs with the remote_managed tag (operators have no control of that at the moment though as an InstancePCIRequest is generated by Nova and VFs are reqeusted). Pools with matching remote_managed PFs could be found first and then PF interface names could be used to filter remote_managed VFs.

Also note: not all VFs of PF devices are necessarily network devices. For example, in the BF2 case there is a VF for SoC management over PCIe (15b3:0061) so this behavior may have unnecessary side-effects.

[copied from the comment below]

Trying to sum up the cases:

1) Matching VFs of a specific PF only: PF PCI address is specified with a vendor and device IDs of a VF.

   (***will work*** with the current code as we are matching a VF by a PF address at the compute node side during device discovery and dev_type=='type-VF' in the resulting pool send to the scheduler)
  see the trace: https://paste.opendev.org/show/bRN19VBEW2cs6Wu2TOG3/
  Example: passthrough_whitelist = {"address": "0000:82:00.0", "vendor_id": "15b3", "product_id": "101e", "physical_network": null, "remote_managed": "true"}
  where 0000:82:00.0 is an address of a PF.
  AND "101e" is a product id of a VF.
  
2) PF PCI address is specified in the whitelist + remote_managed tag but the vendor and product ID belong to a PF.
   (will be filtered with the current code)
  Example: passthrough_whitelist = {"address": "0000:82:00.0", "physical_network": null, "remote_managed": "true"}
  
  where "a2d6" is a product id of a PF.
  
3) (will be filtered with the current code) PF PCI address is specified along with PF vendor and product id in the whitelist + remote_managed tag;
  (will be filtered with the current code)
  Example: passthrough_whitelist = {"address": "0000:82:00.0", "vendor_id": "15b3", "product_id": "a2d6", "physical_network": null, "remote_managed": "true"}
  
  where "a2d6" is a product id of a PF.
In cases (2) and (3) the PFs will end up being exposed in pools and need to be filtered for allocation purposes but they could be used, for example, to avoid filtering VFs that do not have the remote_managed tag specified in the pci_whitelist for which we automatically set it to false.

So when you say "consider PF that are tagged as remote managed" do you mean that I need to support cases (2) and (3)?

Does that seem sane or do I misunderstand it?

Done
This feels hackish. Can we improve on this somehow? Maybe in a follow up refactoring pci/utils to do a comparison with normal equality?
OK. That explains it. Let's keep this as is.

Hm, as far as I understand the current matching code it actually calls __eq__() (or __neq__())  on the attribute of the dev to compare it to the field in the request. So I assume if both field contains a boolean the the comparison would work out of the box. I haven't tried it though. What I see that you set a string to the spec here in [1] and I think that forces you to set a sting also here for the dev to make it match.

What I don't see if the spec model will enforce that only strings can be stored.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/824835/10/nova/network/neutron.py#2319

The string conversion is there because of the serialization of InstancePciRequest objects which come from Nova API:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/26ce7b30b2ea3ff921df3515f98669f1197caa47/nova/compute/api.py#L1083-L1086

The spec attribute is a `ListOfDictOfNullableStringsField`:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/26ce7b30b2ea3ff921df3515f98669f1197caa47/nova/objects/instance_pci_requests.py#L40
        'spec': fields.ListOfDictOfNullableStringsField(),

So, yes, that's why the string conversion is taking place.

So what comes in a request will definitely be a string forcing me to avoid using bool for pools in this function or when converting tags obtained from the devspec in `_create_pool_keys_from_dev`.

In this case a pool is a dict with any value type

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/26ce7b30b2ea3ff921df3515f98669f1197caa47/nova/pci/stats.py#L37
Pool = ty.Dict[str, ty.Any]

but the problem is with what comes in a request.

Possibly, I am open to discussing how pci_device_prop_match could be extended to take types into account but there's no type information associated with keys themselves yet. Maybe besides storing constants in nova/pci/request.py we can also store their respective types to be used for conversion in stats.py so that the comparison can be done normally.
so this is True if all the specs in the request said nothing about remote_manged or said no remote_manged device
... and in this case we remove all pool that has a positive remote_managed tag

so if no remote-managed device is requested then we remove those from the pools. 

However when remote-managed device is requested then we return all pools even those that has non remote-managed device. 

I agree with the first part, but I don't know why we keep non remote-managed device pools in the possibilities if the request wants a remote-managed device.

Ohh I see now. Thanks for the explanation! Now I'm wondering... would it be simpler to default the remote_managed tag to false in the request? Would that remove the need for the special case handling here? (probably yes) Would that cause any trouble for the non remote managed ports? (I don't know)

I recall doing that initially, however, Sean asked me to move it here rather than keeping it at the "client side" because it would cause issues with existing state of device objects on upgrade because they will not have "remote_managed" tags:

https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-11-16.log.html#t2021-11-16T15:25:55
Good point. Upgrade would be harder. I would add a note in the code about this reasoning.

That will be handled by _filter_pools_for_spec above which also calls pci_device_prop_match.

Those pools where `remote_managed` is not present or `remote_managed == "false"` will get filtered out if a request contains `remote_managed == "true"`.

In other words, if specific tag values are not requested, they normally not used in matching. If they are, they must all be there with the requested value per the existing logic in `_filter_pools_for_spec->pci_device_prop_match`

So, I basically got this working for free with the existing logic but needed to special-case the situation where `remote_managed == "true"` in a pool but it is not in the request. That's the key behavior change compared to custom tags that are not special-cased.

Added in:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/827839/1/nova/pci/stats.py#119
how this 'if' is different from the one above it? Is something missing between these two ifs?

My bad, that was supposed to be removed after the logic of `_filter_pools_for_remote_managed_pf_devices` (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/824834/2/nova/pci/stats.py#504) got moved closer to the whitelist validation.

Because deployed ceph runs before /etc/hosts is configured on the overcloud, and this call can return the FQDN of the UC, the following failure is possible:

Error initializing source docker://undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/rh-osbs/rhceph:5-67: error pinging docker registry undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787: Get \"https://undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local:8787/v2/\": dial tcp: lookup undercloud-0.ctlplane.redhat.local: no such host"

openstack_dashboard/management/commands/.message:
sys.path is a list of directories. Looking at the importlib document [1], it looks like that 'path' is not a list of paths but a path. Is this the right usage of find_spec()?

For further discussion, see my comment in the next line.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/importlib.html#importlib.abc.MetaPathFinder.find_spec
we should consider the case when the spec is not found.
You are correct and the argument should be a package name instead of the path's'.

I think the new logic looks impatible with the original code.

Assume module_name is 'horizon.tables'.

When we use imp,

 >>> r = imp.find_module('horizon', sys.path)
 >>> r
 (None, '/Users/motoki/src/opendev.org/openstack/horizon/horizon', ('', '', 5))
 >>> r[1]
 '/Users/motoki/src/opendev.org/openstack/horizon/horizon'
 >>> imp.find_module('tables', [r[1]])
 (None, '/Users/motoki/src/opendev.org/openstack/horizon/horizon/tables', ('', '', 5))

When we use importlib,

 >>> r = importlib.util.find_spec('horizon', sys.path)
 >>> r
 ModuleSpec(name='horizon', loader=<_frozen_importlib_external.SourceFileLoader object at 0x1081c6460>, origin='/Users/motoki/src/opendev.org/openstack/horizon/horizon/__init__.py', submodule_search_locations=['/Users/motoki/src/opendev.org/openstack/horizon/horizon'])
 >>> r.origin
'/Users/motoki/src/opendev.org/openstack/horizon/horizon/__init__.py'

The point is that there is a case where 'spec.origin' contains not a directory but a file path. In this case, spec.origin cannot be used as "path" here.
As a result, the new logic cannot find a module path for 'horizon.tables'.
I think the usage of find_spec you descried is correct. The previous implementation was wrong and doesn't try checking each element, which I've fixed in the latest version.

I wonder this function get_module_path() can be replaced like below:

  spec = importlib.util.find_spec(module_name)
  return spec.origin

get_module_path() is used only in this file (L.106 below).
Perhaps we can drop get_module_path() function and use importlib directly around L.106.

basic question: Why do we need to loop one by one from the parent?
Is it becuase find_spec('foo.bar.baz') raises an ModuleNotFoundError if 'foo.bar' does not exist, right?
Hmm... this was also wrong and imp.find_module would fail with ImortError if the module_name is not actually a module_name. I'll revert this back...

My understanding about this implementation is that it deals with the case where foo.baa is the module name and baz is the name of an object defined in that module(like os.path.exists ).
In this case we can't use the whole path but need to us the actual module name(os.path) to which the instance belongs.
elements[0:0] returns []. I wonder idx needs to start from 1.

question: when is AttributeError raised?
Doesn't 'origin' attribute always exist when spec is not None?
Hmm... it might be wrong that I'm testing it with os.path. I'll recheck this.

I misunderstood the traceback but it seems ModuleNotFoundError is raised when importing an object instead of a module.

```
>>> importlib.util.find_spec('os.path.exists')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/importlib/util.py", line 96, in find_spec
    parent_path = parent.__path__
AttributeError: module 'posixpath' has no attribute '__path__'

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/importlib/util.py", line 98, in find_spec
    raise ModuleNotFoundError(
ModuleNotFoundError: __path__ attribute not found on 'os.path' while trying to find 'os.path.exists'
```
This function get_module_path() expects a module name as an argument, so I don't think we need to take account into the case with an attribute like openstack_dashboard.settings.DEBUG.
I reproduced the same with openstack_dashboards.settings.DEBUG for example but this is not a valid use case according to my observation to the first point. So I revert this back.

This code raises ModuleNotFoundError if non-existing module is specified as a parent module (e.g., "foo.bar" does not exist for "foo.bar.baz"). Howeber, I am not sure we need to cover such cases. The return value of this function is used to calculate the path for "local" dir for the dashboard settings. In addition, DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE should be configured properly by deployers/packagers. Thus, I am fine with this logic.

(Honestly, I don't understand why sys.path needs to be considered, but it is a separate thing.)

Hmm... sys.path is used for the first iteration of find_module but it should not be used after that. If the module can't be loaded then find_module raises an Exception thus it does never return sys.path... so we should avoud returning sys.path actually.

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message:
This could probably use a note from the commit message.  Maybe:

If our layout UUID already matches the UUID in ZK, we don't need to refresh the pipeline state.  But we do still need to update our local change queue objects.

> Just making sure I understand this properly. The change as proposed doesn't affect this scenario right? We'll fall through since the uuid values won't match and then we call resetOrCreate()?

Yep.  Just exposition.  :)

> The failing test_semaphore test case is failing due to the new scheduler not having done this and the build
being unable to run because the scheduler that does have this info is not holding the lock?

Almost -- it's failing due to the new scheduler not having done this and then running the semaphore cleanup method and detecting it as a leaked semaphore since it doesn't have the build info.  The semaphore fix change corrects this by explicitly doing a lookup in ZK in the cleanup method.

Let's clarify this a bit.

We call this after loading a tenant.  If we are the first to reconfigure a tenant, then the pipeline state layout uuid will be the old value, and layout.uuit will be the new one.  In that case, we need to call the pipeline state reset method in order to move the queues currently in zk to "old_queues" so that the next processing pass will re-enqueue them.

Otherwise, we're note the first to reconfigure the tenant, meaning that some other scheduler has already done that, so we can skip it.  We only need to update our local object pointers.

There's one more case: we're a scheduler that's starting up and joining an existing system.  Now, there's a side effect of calling the reset method in the first case: it also refreshes the objects from ZK.  That's important in this case because that's going to initially load the queue items and all the places in our code which are "best-effort", like stats, will have a chance of having something accurate.

In other words, by making this optimization, we're reducing the accuracy of our best-effort routines, especially in the case of scheduler startup.  Maybe that's okay, but it's worth noting.

> There's one more case: we're a scheduler that's starting up and joining an existing system.  Now, there's a side effect of calling the reset method in the first case: it also refreshes the objects from ZK.  That's important in this case because that's going to initially load the queue items and all the places in our code which are "best-effort", like stats, will have a chance of having something accurate.

The failing test_semaphore test case is failing due to the new scheduler not having done this and the build being unable to run because the scheduler that does have this info is not holding the lock?

> 
> In other words, by making this optimization, we're reducing the accuracy of our best-effort routines, especially in the case of scheduler startup.  Maybe that's okay, but it's worth noting.

zuul/scheduler.py.message: Agree, I think we can remove this.

I worry about refreshing the pipeline state, but only if statsd is configured.  Especially with a change like this where we're trying to reduce locking/refreshing/etc based on the idea that it's handled elsewhere, it seems that being consistent would be good.  Maybe we should move the refresh to outside the statsd check?  (Or, more likely, move the statsd check to below this point.)

The thing is that we don't really need to refresh the pipelines if statsd is not configured. So the consistency I was after is to only refresh when necessary, which is not the case without statsd.

But what makes me thinking is that we are executing this only as part of a reconfig, which should refresh the pipeline in the post config hook when resetting the state. So the refresh here shouldn't be necessary, but we should at least have a comment describing that behavior.
Yes, as it turns out.  lock_ctx is a generator, and tlock is the actual lock...
Ah yup tenant_write_lock returns a SessionAwareWriteLock which we must then enter a context with to actually acquire the lock.
...that we pass in here.  Apparently this is untested code, because it does fail if I stick a refresh here.  Ideally, we would move this into its own change and add a test.

This is not true anymore.  This change removes the refresh that happens on loading a tenant, so now we can enter this clause with an out of date pipeline state.  When a scheduler starts and joins an existing system, it will have no items in its queues until it manages to process them.

See the other comment about the side effect of refresh on startup.

I think we need to do one of the following here:

1) Remove this stats emission altogether.  In <v5 it's purpose was to reset gauges on startup.  Now the gauges aren't likely to be wrong for very long after a reconfiguration (if they're wrong at all).  And as written, it can zero out the gauges when a scheduler comes online.

2) Add a refresh to this location (as in the earlier patchset).

3) Add a refresh to the end of the config priming method so that we load some data in on scheduler startup for best-effort methods like this.

My preference is #1.

This does not fix the bug, which is that a 400 is being returned when it shouldn't be.  All you are doing is adding a warning message that will show up in the log (which the end user cannot see) and the call will still fail (which the end user will see).

I think what's going on here is that if you have a group containing volumes V1, V2, V3, and then you do a group-update that only adds V1, V2, V3 to the group, you get a 400 because the code can't tell if the add list is empty because it is empty in the request, or if it's empty because the validation code removed all the volumes because they were all already in the group.  See comments inline.

I'm not in favor of adding a warning log message for something that's not an error condition.  I think you should just fix the root cause.

zuul/zk/semaphore.py.message: Any ideas how we could also take care of cleaning up leaked legacy handles?

I think there is also a bigger issue here. It looks like we can't use the new-style handle format until all other schedulers are updated aswell. Otherwise the old schedulers would consider the new style handles leaked and clean them up.

Looks like we need to bump/use the model API version here :/
I updated the change to use the model API version, but we still won't be able to clean up leaked legacy handlers.
TODO: use the "kind"-filter here that is introduced in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/828292/1/zuul/zk/components.py
TODO: use the "kind"-filter here that is introduced in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/828292/1/zuul/zk/components.py

I think your analysis in the first paragraph is correct.  It can switch in the middle of this loop, but it's fine because we read both formats.

Basically, the world starts on version 1 with legacy data.  One scheduler restarts with the ability to support the new format but does not use it, it only writes the legacy format for now.  Once the entire cluster is able to read the new format, schedulers start writing the new format for new data.  Eventually old data ages out, ideally.

I'm not in a rush to remove backwards compat handling.  The model api log has release version numbers in it so we can determine that in this case, we can't remove backwards compat until at after the version after 5.0.0  (ie, this code ends up in 5.1.0, then in 5.2.0 at minimum we could remove the backwards compat, with a release note indicating that running on at least 5.1.0 for some time is needed).

We could attempt to migrate the data format en-masse like alembic... we could probably iterate over all the semaphore holders and upgrade them.  That would be non-trivial (would require locking and loading in all the pipeline states and doing a lookup), but possible.

So yeah, in short, I think we either have to add a bunch of extra code here to migrate data, or assume that people will run intermediate versions long enough for the data to age out.  "zuul delete-state" is the alternative if that doesn't work.  And yes, that would be necessary too if there's some kind of leak.

Is there any concern that this model_api value can shift from 1 to 2 while we have semaphore_holders in the old format? I suppose if that happens we are ok because we continue to check the lock using both formats and release using both formats.

Maybe we need a release note indicating people should update to the new model api version and sit there a bit to let things cycle out before doing another model update? Though I think we're trying to make this transparent? But I think they may want to avoid updating straight to whatever change ends up removing the checks and removals using both handles. And instead get to this version, then sit a bit, then update to the cleanup version.

Also this doesn't touch on what will happen if there are leaks and sitting for a bit doesn't clear out the old data. I guess manual intervention would be required in that case before updating to a version that cannot handle the legacy format?

I don't think that a data migration system is necessary. It should be sufficient for this case and its child if we simply tell people to iterate through zuul releases when upgrading. Something that is now far less costly if running multiple schedulers as it can be done without downtime.

For now, but only in the short term.

> In effect, as I understand it, we'll stop supporting online rolling upgrades, so a release note is necessary.

Nope, we're not going to do anything silly like that 😄 This is just prepping for the introduction of alembic but we haven't added anything yet. In the alembic'ful future, we're still going to split our migrations, albeit into branches instead of repos (we're also going to only have two branches - expand and contract - since this is what neutron does and it's perfectly okay for them). These tests just need to be updated/duplicated+reworked to test the new alembic-based migration flow. That has to happen when we integrate alembic fully. The end result should be quite similar: after all, in an alembic-based world, instead of checking if e.g. we're using destructive operations in the expand *repo*, we'll simply check if we're using these operations in the expand *branch*.

Hopefully this clears up any confusion.

I took reference from the existing wait mechanism but modified on the basis of how much time it should take in a real deployment.
Here wait time will be in the following order,
wait = 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 8, 10(should be 16 but resize should not take more than max_recheck_wait = 10)
elapsed = 0.5, 1.5, 3.5, 7.5, 15.5, 25.5(this case will raise exception as timeout is set to 20 seconds)
In an actual deployment with slightly slow networks, it should take 1-2 seconds for the resize to take effect in the device but just for caution if the network is really slow, we wait for a maximum time of 20 seconds spanning over 5 retries which is significantly more than how much it will take in a real scenario but just to be on the safe side (and also we won't wait unnecessarily if the device gets resized earlier)
I didn't make these values configurable as it is not a common usecase and can happen rarely in a deployment and the operator can't assume the desired time required for this resize to occur as it is not obvious to determine it. Also the current set time is far more than what will be required in a real deployment.

Regarding the second query, yes that's the right understanding and that can be addressed by a unit test as we've tested similar cases with the help of unit test only. Any exception occurring in the image writing logic leads to deletion of volume and we already have tests related to that. I will add a unit test in next PS for this case.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Can you mention what is requiring it?

Ok .. the bootstrap task that fails is the "Generate Helm repo indicies", this makes use of the "become_user: www" since www is the owner of the helm charts, however, www is an unprivileged user to create temporary files and that is the problem:

"Failed to set permissions on the temporary files Ansible needs to create when becoming an unprivileged user"

Ansible doc mentions 3 solutions for this:

1. Use pipelining, in which a temporary file is not created
2. Install POSIX acl, since setfacl utility is used to share the file with the unprivileged user
3. Don't use the "become_user" to an unprivileged user

It seems that CentOS makes use of number 2, acl is installed.

Yet another option could be explored: the use of the variable "allow_world_readable_tmpfiles", but not sure if we would like to explore it.

Other point to note is that if Ansible ran as root it seems this would not happen, however, this does not seem to be a good solution or even desired as per permission restriction reasons.

This kind of "deep" mocking isn't great, and there's a better way to do this. When we talked about this during our internal RH tech call, Sean Mooney came up with the following idea:

1. Use self.flags() to set max_concurrent_live_migrations to 1.

2. Boot a VM and live migrate it, using mocking/stubbing to leave it running during the following steps. We'll probably need to use the libvirt functional tests for this, where we can stub migrateToURI3 to do whatever we want and not complete until we decide to.

3. Boot a second VM and live migrate it, then abort the live migration. Assert the broken rollback behaviour.

4. Complete the live migration from step 2.

IMO this would require to stub out nova.tests.fixtures.libvirt.Domain.migrateToURI3 because it is not implemented for fake_libvirt. It makes sense because we would complete simulation instead of stopping test in the process, so I would add appropriate code.

self.lock.aquire() 

get the lock before launching the instnaces

then here release the lock so the server can finsih migrating
